    Getting Started

Getting Started with gbifrules

getting-started.Rmd

Introduction

The gbifrules package provides an R interface to the GBIF (Global Biodiversity Information Facility) rule-based annotation store. This package allows you to:

  • Create and manage annotation projects
  • Define rules to flag suspicious occurrence records
  • Clean GBIF downloads using your annotation rules
  • Collaborate with other users on annotation projects

Installation

You can install gbifrules from GitHub:

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("gbif/occurrence-annotation", subdir = "r-package/gbifrules")

Authentication

Before using the package, you need to set up your GBIF credentials. The easiest way is to add them to your .Renviron file:

usethis::edit_r_environ()

Add these lines to the file that opens:

GBIF_USER="your_username"
GBIF_PWD="your_password"
GBIF_EMAIL="your_email@example.com"

Save the file and restart R for the changes to take effect.

Quick Start

Creating a Project

Projects help organize your annotation rules:

library(gbifrules)

# Create a new project
my_project <- make_project(
  name = "Invasive Species Monitoring",
  description = "Flagging potentially invasive species occurrences"
)

Creating a Simple Rule

Let’s create a rule to flag Ambystoma mexicanum (Mexican axolotl) records outside their native range:

# Define the native range (rough polygon around Mexico)
native_range <- "POLYGON((-106 19, -106 21, -98 21, -98 19, -106 19))"

# Create the rule
rule <- make_rule(
  projectId = my_project$id,
  taxonKey = 431950,  # Ambystoma mexicanum
  notGeometry = native_range,
  annotation = "INVASIVE",
  annotationComment = "Ambystoma mexicanum outside native range in Mexico"
)

This rule will flag any A. mexicanum records that fall outside the specified polygon.

Advanced Filtering

You can create more complex rules with additional filters:

# Flag only preserved specimens from recent years
rule <- make_rule(
  projectId = my_project$id,
  taxonKey = 431950,
  notGeometry = native_range,
  basisOfRecord = list("PRESERVED_SPECIMEN"),
  yearRange = list(min = 2010),
  annotation = "INVASIVE",
  annotationComment = "Recent preserved specimens outside native range"
)

Cleaning Downloaded Data

Once you have rules set up, you can use them to clean GBIF downloads:

# Download some data using rgbif
library(rgbif)

d <- occ_download_get("0051416-241126133413365") %>%
  occ_download_import()

# Clean the data using your project's rules
cleaned_data <- clean_download(d, project_id = my_project$id)

# Or filter by multiple projects
cleaned_data <- clean_download(d, project_id = c(1, 2, 3))

Managing Rules

You can view, support, or contest existing rules:

# Get a specific rule
rule_info <- get_rule(rule$id)

# Support a rule
support_rule(rule$id)

# Contest a rule with a comment
contest_rule(
  ruleId = rule$id,
  comment = "This range definition seems too restrictive"
)

Next Steps

  • Explore the function reference for detailed documentation
  • Check out the annotation types available in GBIF
  • Collaborate with others by adding project members using add_project_member()

Getting Help

If you encounter issues or have questions:

  • Check the GitHub repository
  • Review the function documentation: ?make_rule, ?clean_download, etc.
